inlineContent.text: KeyboardKit helps you build custom keyboards with Swift and SwiftUI. It extends Apple’s native keyboard extension APIs and provides you with a lot more functionality than is otherwise available.
KeyboardKit also provides you with utilities that lets you mimic native iOS keyboards. You can use
and style it a little (or a lot) or use completely custom views or designs.
Although KeyboardKit builds on all platform, some features are unavailable on some platforms.
The best way to add KeyboardKit to your app is to use the Swift Package Manager.
You can add the library to the main app, the keyboard extension and any other targets that need it.
The online documentation is currently iOS only. To generate documentation for other platforms, open the package in Xcode, select a simulator then run
Note that type extensions are not included in this documentation.
KeyboardKit is available under the MIT license.

abstract.text: KeyboardKit helps you build custom keyboards with Swift and SwiftUI.
This disabled player doesn’t do anything and can be used on
platforms where system audio is not available.
This menu can be used to list a set of emoji categories and
let each category button toggle a category selection.

to customize
things like the font, number of rows, item spacing etc.
This class provides U.S. English callout actions.
This standard callout action provider takes a collection of

This input set can be used in symbolic keyboards.
This struct represents a keyboard input item with a neutral,
an uppercased and a lowercased string.
This enum defines the various ways a user can interact with
keyboard actions, using KeyboardKit’s built-in interactions.
This typealias represents a row of input set items.
This protocol can be implemented by classes that can handle
drag gestures from a start position to a current one.
This view replicates the standard autocomplete toolbar item
separator that is used in native iOS keyboards.
This typealias specifies the standard button content that a
will use by default.
This view mimics a system keyboard space button with custom
content that takes up as much horizontal space as needed.
This is an observable class that can be used to store a set
of autocomplete suggestions.
This callout can be used to show the currently typed action
above the pressed keyboard button.
This view replicates the standard autocomplete toolbar item
subtitle text that is used in native iOS keyboards.
This article describes the KeyboardKit autocomplete model and how to use it.
This style can be applied to
views to control the color and width of the separator line.
This protocol can be implemented by classes that can return
a list of emojis.
This keyboard layout provider bases its layout decisions on
the type of device used. It will toggle between an
and
specific layout provider.
This view is the part of the callout that covers the button
that was tapped or pressed to trigger the callout.
This article describes the KeyboardKit keyboard layout concept and how to use it.
This view can be used when you want to have multi-line text
input in a keyboard extension, and the input should receive
the text that is typed on the keyboard.
This enum describes various ways in which a keyboard layout
can size its items.

can be used to list actions in a grid with
a certain number of
This enum contains KeyboardKit-supported locales.
This typealias represents a
array.
This context can be used to handle callouts that show a big
version of the currently typed character.
This article describes keyboard actions and how to use action handlers.
This enum represents the state a text document proxy can be
in, when inserting and removing spaces during autocomplete.
This enum contains all keyboard types that can currently be
bound to the
switch keyboard action.
This view mimics native iOS system keyboards, like standard
alphabetic, numeric and symbolic system keyboards.
This enum can be used to change the drag sensitivity of the
spacebar.
This protocol can be used to specify behavior rules for the
keyboard. It aims to separate behavior from action handling
to make the code cleaner and more understandable.
This disabled player doesn’t do anything and can be used on
platforms where haptic feedback is not available.
This view mimics the buttons that are used in an iOS system
keyboard. It wraps a
view and uses a
to resolves its content.
This view mimics the content of a system space button, that
starts with displaying the provided
then fades
to the
(or
This enum contains keyboard-specific, resource-based colors.
This enum can be used to vary how the backspace action will
behave when pressing and holding the backspace key.
This class provides keyboard extensions with contextual and
observable information. It is a central part of KeyboardKit
and to create adaptive keyboards.
This input set provider provides English input sets.
This view can be used when you want to have a text field in
a keyboard extension, and the text field should receive the
text that is typed on the keyboard.
A keyboard layout item provides a keyboard action, the item
size and insets. It can then be converted to a button.
This article describes the KeyboardKit feedback model and how to use it.
This article describes the KeyboardKit localization model and how to use it.
A keyboard layout defines all available keyboard actions on
a keyboard, as well as their size.
This enum contains keyboard-specific, resource-based texts.
This curve can be used to smoothen the part where a callout
bubble meets the button area.
This appearance can be used in SwiftUI previews.
This class provides a keyboard layout that correspond to an
iPad with a home button.
This typealias specifies the standard button view, that the
will use by default.
This struct is a standard suggestion that can be used by an
autocomplete suggestion provider.
This context can be used to handle callouts that show a set
of alternate actions for a certain keyboard action.
This struct provides the size of a keyboard layout item. It
has a regular height, but a declarative width.
KeyboardKit helps you build custom keyboards with Swift and SwiftUI.
This struct can be used to specify a keyboard configuration
for e.g. a certain device.
This protocol can be implemented by services that are bound
to a certain locale. It simplifies aggregating services and
resolve the correct service for a certain locale.
This view renders a standard button for an emoji.
This article discusses how to configure KeyboardKit and add your own logic to the mix.
This view resolves the correct content for a certain action,
which will result in either a text or image, or nothing. It
also sets up line limits, vertical offsets etc.
This view mimics the buttons that are used in an iOS system
keyboard. It wraps the provided content and applies a style.
This input set provider is initialized with a collection of
localized providers and will use the provider with the same
locale as the context.
This player uses system features to prepare and play haptic
feedback. It’s the default
player on all
platforms where it’s supported.
This protocol can be implemented by any classes that can be
used to provide
values for keyboard layouts.
This behavior can be used to define a behavior that doesn’t
cause any changes to the keyboard when typing.
This callout can be used to present alternate actions for a
keyboard certain keyboard action.
This keyboard layout provider returns the layout that it is
initialized with, without any additional logic.
This class makes it possible to redirect a keyboard’s typed
text from the main app to another custom text input. It can
be used to add text fields to the keyboard extension itself.
This protocol can be implemented by any classes that can be
used to generate a
for a certain context.
This typealias represents a list of layout item rows.
This layout provider can be used in SwiftUI previews.
This article describes the KeyboardKit input set concept and how to use it.
This input set can be used in alphabetic keyboards.
This protocol can be implemented by classes that can play a
system audio sound, referred by id.
This action provider can be used in SwiftUI previews.
This view can be used to list an emoji collection using the
provided configuration.
This standard appearance returns styles that replicates the
look of a native system keyboard.
This enum contains various haptic feedback types.
This private class is used to handle repeating actions on a
keyboard button.
This style can be applied to customize the appearance of an
s background.
This view mimics text in a system keyboard button.
This view is a horizontal row with autocomplete buttons and
separator lines between the buttons.
This keyboard lists all emojis from a selected category, as
well as a menu that lets the user select a new category and
change back to an alphabetic keyboard.
This style can be applied to
s to customize
things like the callout style, padding, font etc.
This view renders a standard title for an emoji category.
This action handler can be used in SwiftUI previews.
This input set provider just returns the input sets that it
was initialized with.
This struct is just a wrapper around a single character. It
can be used to get a little bit of type safety, and to work
more structured with emojis.
This view represents the body of a standard system keyboard
button, excluding the button text or image.
This style defines the style of a system keyboard button.
This view replicates the standard autocomplete toolbar item
title text that is used in native iOS keyboards.

by keeping a published
in sync with the
state of the associated keyboard.

that is

protocol.
This class can be inherited by any keyboard layout provider
that needs basic functionality for creating system keyboard
layouts that depend on system-specific rules.
This view replicates the standard autocomplete toolbar item
that is used in native iOS keyboards.
This class can be used to specify what kind of feedback the
current keyboard should give to the user.
This struct can be used to style callout views, which are a
type of view that is presented above a keyboard button, e.g.
when a user types or long presses a key to get more actions.
This enum lists the various shift states a keyboard can use.
This button shows an image with a tap and long press action.
This typealias represents a list of layout items.
This enum can be used to specify the type of device without

This view represents the bottom shadow of a standard system

to be added as an overlay, and will cut out the shadow that

This emoji provider can be used to return the most recently
used emojis.
This protocol can be implemented by any classes that can be
used to trigger audio and haptic feedback to the user.

views.

array.

This class provides a keyboard layout that correspond to an
iPhone with either a home button or notch.
This protocol describes result data that can be returned by

This article describes the KeyboardKit appearance model and how to use it.
This enum defines keyboard-specific actions that correspond
to actions that can be found on various keyboards. Keyboard
actions are fundamental building-blocks in the library.
This document proxy can be used in SwiftUI previews.
This typealias represents a list of input set rows.
This class defines how a standard, Western keyboard behaves.
This protocol can be implemented by any classes that can be
used to prepare and play haptic feedback.
This protocol can be implemented by any class or struct and

This protocol extends
and can be used by
any provider that bases its input set on the current device.
This protocol can be implemented by any type that is stored
in “rows” that should be easily mutated.
This protocol can be implemented by any classes that can be

This drag gesture handler handles the space key cursor move

being edited.
This struct specifies haptic feedback for a custom keyboard.

s.

This player uses system features to play system audio. It’s
the default
player on platforms where it is

This input set can used in numeric keyboards.
This style defines the shadow of a system keyboard button.
This struct specifies audio feedback for a custom keyboard.
This article discusses how to install KeyboardKit and get started using it in your app.
This protocol can be implemented by classes that can handle
events.
This protocol can be implemented by classes that can return

An input set defines the input keys on a keyboard. The keys
can then be used to create a keyboard layout, which defines
the full set of keys, including the surrounding system keys.
This class can be used to detect whether or not an external
keyboard is connected to the device.
This class simplifies creating callout action providers, by

This class extends
with KeyboardKit
specific functionality.
This input set provider can be used in SwiftUI previews.
This standard keyboard action handler is used by default by
KeyboardKit and provides a standard way of handling actions.
This is a hopefully temporary class that can be used to get
SwiftUI previews to work outside of the KeyboardKit package.
This view is meant to be used within a
and
will apply the frames and paddings to the view, to mitigate
